title: Montini: Cowardly congressmen cower...oh my
text:

Bert Lahr as the Cowardly Lion in the 1939 'Wizard of Oz' (Photo: MGM) 
They have the week off. 
The Republicans serving Arizona in Congress could have taken the opportunity to hold town halls where they would listen to your concerns about issues like health care and immigration and the environment and education and the many appointments being made by President Donald Trump and so on. 
But in other parts of the country Republican members of Congress have faced hostile crowds . That is to say, they have faced constituents -- voters -- with actual concerns. Men and women who want to know specifics about what their representatives have planned for them. Vote for me, then bugger off 
In Arizona, our cowardly congressional lions are off cowering somewhere, afraid to meet you face to face. 
It's pathetic. 
They beg for your vote. They take your money. They enjoy all the privileges afforded to members of Congress. The kind of privileges ordinary people couldn't imagine. Travel. Access. Opportunity. 
MONTINI: Are McCain and Flake afraid of you? 
All that you ask - and should expect - is service. 
That means looking you in the eye and telling you what they're going to do, how they're going to vote, who they're going to support, even if they know it might make you angry. 
Especially then, because you pay their salaries. You deserve that much. 
Instead, you're getting a lot less. They mocked Kirkpatrick for this CLOSE x Share Arizona's senators need to use more rubber mallet and less rubber stamp with President Trump, columnist E.J. Montini says. 
Some small groups of constituents have been trying to flush out our cowering congressmen, but without any luck. 
Remember how former Rep. Ann Kirkpatrick was ridiculed in a campaign commercial for having run out of a town hall? I'd guess that a lot of people voted for Sen. John McCain in the Senate race because of those ads. Now, neither McCain nor Sen. Jeff Flake are holding town halls during the week off. 
MORE: Trump goes after 'so-called angry crowds' in GOP districts 
And neither are any of our Republican congressmen, for whom it would actually mean something, since Republicans control both the Senate and the House. There is a Republican president. They control the legislative process. They can do anything they want. And they have chosen to do is ignore you. 
Avoid you. 
Disrespect you. How to contact your absent lawmakers 
You could contact them by telephone. Maybe. Depending on whether their messaging systems are functioning. And depending on whether they actual listen to those messages. 
Rep. Paul Gosar’s Arizona office can be reached at (928) 445-1683 or his Washington office at (202) 225-2315. 
Rep. Andy Biggs’s Arizona office can be reached at at (480) 699-8239 or his Washington office at (202) 225-2635. 
Rep. David Schweikert’s Arizona office can be reached at (480) 946-2411 or his Washington office at (202) 225-2190. 
Rep. Trent Franks's Arizona office can be reached at (623) 776-7911 or his Washington office at (202) 225-4576. 
None of them scheduled town halls open to the public during their recess week. As candidates they roar like lions. As congressmen they cower. 
No courtesy, candor or courage.
